summary: If Sansa had gone to meet Cersei instead of Brienne with Jon and Daenerys, it would have been so,,, sweet. There would have been...
body: If Sansa had gone to meet Cersei instead of Brienne with Jon and Daenerys, it would have been so,,, sweet. There would have been so many reunions, Sansa and Theon, Sansa and Tyrion, Sansa and the Hound.

blog.name: turtle-paced
blog.title: turtle-paced
blog.description: Writing at the speed of the race course paradox.

summary: A lot of people, me included, have tried to think of a better way for Ned to have handled Jon than claiming him as his own...
question: A lot of people, me included, have tried to think of a better way for Ned to have handled Jon than claiming him as his own bastard with all the unfortunate treatment that entailed, including Catelyn's ill-will.  But from your response about how he wants to keep Jon out of Robert's mind, doesn't that make his bastard status a feature, not a bug, for pretty much the same reasons LF voices to Sansa about her cover?
answer:
Yep. Absolutely. It’s rude to pry into the origins of a man’s bastard children, so Littlefinger says, and so Ned’s reluctance to give any more details of Jon’s birth than “this is Jon, he’s my bastard” is completely acceptable and in fact expected. Nobody asks Ned any questions, and Ned doesn’t have to go into detail with the lies.

“Ned’s bastard” is by far the safest way to conceal Jon’s biological parentage. It’s the terrible, patriarchal, feudal society this story takes place in that means the best way to preserve and nurture the life of innocent Jon is to humiliate also-innocent Catelyn.

It’s rude to pry into the origins of a man’s bastard children, so Littlefinger says, and so Ned’s reluctance to give any more details of Jon’s birth than “this is Jon, he’s my bastard” is completely acceptable and in fact expected. Nobody asks Ned any questions, and Ned doesn’t have to go into detail with the lies.

“Ned’s bastard” is by far the safest way to conceal Jon’s biological parentage. It’s the terrible, patriarchal, feudal society this story takes place in that means the best way to preserve and nurture the life of innocent Jon is to humiliate also-innocent Catelyn.

summary: Assuming R+L=J is true, do you think it would have change Cats opinion of Jon if Ned told her? I'd ask what Robert would say but...
question: Assuming R+L=J is true, do you think it would have change Cats opinion of Jon if Ned told her? I'd ask what Robert would say but we all know he just see Jon as a dragon spawn rape baby
answer:
While I think Catelyn would be more sympathetic to Jon personally if she knew about R+L=J, I seriously think it would be totally swallowed up in horror that Ned brought who home with him? Ned is lying to the king about what? He’s putting their children in how much danger now?

Ned could never tell Catelyn, because telling her puts her in a position where either she becomes complicit in his treason and perpetuates the danger to their children, or she has to make Ned’s treason known, sacrificing Ned and Jon for the safety of Robb, Sansa, Arya, Bran and Rickon. It’s a question Ned’s asked himself in the series proper.

Ned thought, if it came to that, the life of some child I did not know, against Robb and Sansa and Arya and Bran and Rickon, what would I do? Even more so, what would Catelyn do, if it were Jon’s life, against the children of her body? He did not know. He prayed he never would.

- Eddard XII, AGoT

summary: After that post about gen z memelord!arya and concerned millennial!jon, all I can see is arya finishing a drink, looking down at...
body:
After that post about gen z memelord!arya and concerned millennial!jon, all I can see is arya finishing a drink, looking down at her cup, going “This bitch empty” and then standing up and throwing it as hard as she can across the Great Hall while yelling “YEEET” and everyone else just looks at her like she’s lost it except for bran who is just slow clapping

Bonus points if the cup hits tormund on the head and knocks him out

blog.name: jackoshadows
blog.title: Jak O' the Shadows
blog.description: I’m not going to swear an oath I can’t uphold. Talk about my father if you want. Tell me that’s the attitude that got him killed. But when enough people make false promises, words stop meaning anything. Then there are no more answers - only better and better lies. And lies won’t help us in this fight - Jon Snow.

tags: Political Jon is a really horrible person
Not the political Jon who is a savvy politician in the books
But the LF 2.0 political Jon who gets off on sexually manipulating young women
summary:
GOT script: 
Jon looks to the people whose opinions he values most: Davos. Dany.  Jonsa fandom: Of course he values Dany’s...
body:
GOT script:

Jon looks to the people whose opinions he values most: Davos. Dany. 

Jonsa fandom:

Of course he values Dany’s opinions because he needs to know her to manipulate her! That’s why he is political!Jon.

Me:

Is there anything, anything at all out there that would convince these folks that Jon Snow is not a horrible, horrible person out to seduce and sexually manipulate a woman that he knows has been raped and defiled? Sigh.

blog.title: no homo but girls are breathtaking, bro
blog.description: Izzy. Brazilian. A loving gay relationship based on mutual support is my aesthetic

body:
Northern Warrior

I think we often underestimate how Sansa would react to having a child. This is my take on what would happen.

This focused on Sansa so please, ignore Jon.

-

Sansa feels a sort of giddiness afterwards, a fuzzy feeling that brings a shy smile to her lips. Her body is sore and she can’t walk straight, though she doesn’t find in herself the strength to care about it.

It’s been years since she last felt this way. Before her father’s death, before King’s Landing and before Lady’s death. It’s as if she is that little girl again, smiling more freely and giggling around.

Sometimes, Sansa forgets. Automatically, she places her hand on her stomach, still swollen after just a few days, and when the tattletale little kick on her ribs doesn’t follow, she panics. Crippling and freezing fear, enough to make her curl in herself for just a moment before remembering. The babe is already here.

He is soft and warm. Tormund calls him a loaf of babe, with chubby legs and a sweet face. Sansa can never spend too much time away from him, from her son.

Brandon. Father’s death is still fresh on her mind, too painful to name him after Ned and to start the new generation of Starks with the oldest name in their line seemed fitting. Jon agreed and so her son was named Brandon Stark.

They tell her not to get too attached. Children die often, it’s why tradition dictates one can only be mourned after their twelth nameday. Specially at winter. Brandon could very well catch a fever in the next day.

Sansa will make sure that her son survives, though.

His cot is in her chambers, so she can feed him more quickly when he cries at night. Sometimes, she stays awake after he returns to sleep, zealously watching him. Her eyelids are heavy and she yawns at every second, but treacherous thoughts never leave her mind.

If I stop watching him, he will stop breathing.

One night, he stays awake as well, staring at her with his impossibly big gray eyes and smiling. He likes her. She almost forgets how she is in near tears, wanting to beg him to return to sleep, and smiles back. She strokes a finger down his cheek and his giggles echoes around the room.

Sansa turns to her bed. Jon is still snoring, sprawled over the covers.

“You can’t die,” she tells Brandon, “I need you.”

Carefully, she places her hand behind his soft head and little rump and pulls him to her arms. Brandon sighs, relaxed, and raises a fist to grab a strand of her hair. Weeks have passed since her clumsy state of holding him.

“We will accomplish great things together,” she whispers, rocking him around. “My Brandon, my saviour, my northern warrior.”

My son.
